If you are planning a trip to the Pacific Northwet, you should know that the rainy season begins Oct. 1. And it usually ends around Sep. 30. So you want to try to work around that.

In Florida where Walter lives, they can get 4 inches of rain in an hour, and then the sun will come out. Here in the Northwet, we are much more thrifty. We can take a quarter of an inch, and make it last all day long.

If you look out, and you cannot see Mt. Rainier, then it is raining.  If you CAN see it, then it is going to rain soon.

We have more rain-related jokes here than you might imagine.

@marketwizard87 Saying that a >60% bearish reading now is not necessarily exactly the same as one 30 years ago. It is still high, for sure, and it may be splitting hairs to put too fine a point on the number from a sentiment reading. Last: avoid specific if-then conclusions with small sample.

Fear and greed (in the human brain) have not changed. But our access to opportunities to act on them has changed. And any survey of a population subgroup (like AAII members) is subject to statistical anomalies which should be at least acknowledged by anyone using such data.

Economists think that Volcker succeed in vanquishing inflation with higher rates. This article debunks that theory. https://t.co/HVGNMtO4Ld. It was something else that brought inflation down, in spite of and not because of higher rates.

Higher prices come about because of too much money chasing too few goods and services. Higher rates can attract some of that money away, to earn interest instead of buying stuff. But unless we solve the too few goods problem (which a recession makes worse), the problem persists.

@AlBundy5000 @CNBC The Amazon rainforest grows quite well without humans adding new saplings. It is indeed a problem to have it converted to other purposes. US wildfires, esp. in Calif., are worse largely because of too many trees, i.e. not thinning for forest health. Planting won't solve that.

@GregoryLMorris @CNBC In Pacific Northwest timberland, replanting is done at 300-400 stems per acre. Some of those new plants will die, and some others will sprout naturally. Terminal harvest (at 40-45 years) is ideally done at ~180 trees per acre. So thinning is needed to have a healthy forest.

The point for cosmologists, and for chartists, is that you can go ahead and have an hypothesis of how things should work. But don’t assume things have to work that way when you change the scaling by a lot. And test your hypotheses. [10/10]
…spanning decades, or to tick charts, only to find out that those “rules” do not necessarily work the same when the scaling gets outside of the range for which the rules were developed. [9/10]

This discussion actually has relevance in other areas, like the stock market. Classical bar charting principles were developed years ago for charts of a certain time duration. Some chartists insist on trying to apply them to charts of patterns…  [8/10]

As an aside, my grandfather was an astronomer, former director of the Griffith Park Observatory in Los Angeles, who trained NASA astronauts in stellar navigation. So discussions of astrophysics were part of growing up in my family. [7/10]

This imposition of a non-Newtonian set of rules is not so much of a problem, since we already know that Newton’s laws break down when we get down to subatomic scales. So maybe they break down too at galactic ones. [6/10]

We also hear from cosmologists that there must be undetectable “dark matter” and “dark energy” out there, to explain the physics of the movements of galaxies, which don’t seem to fit Newtonian rules. The math does not work without those. [5/10]

When I have posed this question to physicists, they explain that the rules of physics right after the moment of the Big Bang were different from the rules now, which allows for that rule breaking. I have trouble with that. [4/10]
After 13.8 billion years, those 2 particles would be 27.6 billion light years distant from each other. So how can something be farther away from something else than 27.6 billion light year? [3/10]

This should theoretically not be possible, in a universe that is supposedly 13.8 billion years old (since Big Bang). Imagine 2 particles traveling the speed of light in opposite directions from moment of the Big Bang. [2/10]

I have long had problems with certain assertions made by cosmologists, & am glad that they are finally grappling with the anomalies in their observations. For one thing, there is the problematic observation of spotting galaxies supposedly 30 billion light years from Earth. [1/10]

There does not have to be a headline for last hour moves. It can just be one big PM, or a couple, deciding to hit the buy button and sending a big basket of orders to the trading desk for those guys to hopefully execute in the last hour of the day.
A good reason why an opening bell trend tends to end an hour in, once it has accomplished its mission.

This rally started right at 3PM ET. Big fund firms (think Fidelity) give their PMs until 2:30 or 3PM to get their orders to trading desk, so that traders have time to get them all done before the close. This is why the final hour often sees linear trends on intraday charts.
Aaaaand... The SPX turns green.

@CarpeDiem010101 There is a ratio-adjusted version available, as $NYMO or $NAMO, versus the traditional one under $NYMOT or $NAMOT. The ratio-adjusted version is better for such long term comparisons.
@CarpeDiem010101 This is a question of evaluating magnitudes, which are affected by total issues traded, without adjusting for that. It is not an issue of correlation at all.

At the start of 2019, the Nasdaq had ~3300 listed issues. Now it has over 5400. $NAMOT is affected by total issues, so you are not doing a useful historical comparison of values with the unadjusted McClellan Oscillator.

But there is the bond market, which seems to know better than the experts. If the FOMC could learn to listen to the 2-year T-Note yield, and adjust to its message without overtuning to create wowing, we could have a much more efficiently running economic engine. [19/fin]

To be an effective governor on the speed of the economy, the Fed has to have a signal to tell it that things are running too hot or too cold. It does not have that magical economic tachometer to get a speed reading from. [18/19]

One way to see effect of this is using the NYSE A-D Line, which I contend is the best gauge of the health of the liquidity stream. If the Fed is being too stimulative, with rates lower than they should be, the A-D Line does great. Too restrictive, and the A-D Line falls. [17/19] https://t.co/63ZcsSC1WE

Looking at the comparison between the 2-year and the Fed Funds target rate, we see that the Fed seems always a step behind whatever the 2-year yield does. This is precisely the point. The 2-year knows what the Fed should do before the Fed knows it. [16/19] https://t.co/Fe8YOd7rRM

2 years seems to be the sweet spot to get the messaging. 3-month or 6-month yields are a little too short term, and they just match whatever the Fed does directly. 10-year or 30-year bonds are too far out, and are sensitive to other factors (mostly inflation). [15/19]

That is where the 2-year T-Note yield comes in. History shows that the bond market is a better guesser than the Fed experts. Why that is, well, that’s an interesting question, but not an essential one. We can see that it works well enough, without having to know why. [14/19]
See https://t.co/KwpDXlbARr for a description. [12/19] https://t.co/VXI0dd913J
The Fed has to look for signs in other ways, and sometimes it does not do a very good job of that, despite so many economics PhDs serving as official “experts”. [10/19]

GDP is part of it, but there have been times when GDP has been high and inflation low. We have also seen the opposite, stagflation. And GDP is delayed in giving its message. So are CPI and other inflation gauges. [9/19]
Adjusting throttle is tougher to do for the economy than for a simple engine, hence the Fed’s problem. We don’t have a simple tachometer for the economy to tell us the economic engine’s speed. [8/19]
If you say “wow-wow-wow” out loud, you’ll understand why that name applies. [7/19]

The cruise control in your car is a type of a governor, adding throttle if the car slows below the ideal speed setting, or retarding it if speed is too high. Key to any governor is that it must be able to read the speed, and adjust. [5/19]

James Watt developed the first practical steam engine, and it included a “flyball governor”. The faster the shaft spins, the further out the weighted balls would move via centrifugal force, which would then adjust a steam valve. [4/19] https://t.co/5yG8vtEMcv https://t.co/lXGZyFR2QB
The solution is a “governor”, which adjusts the throttle setting to match the load on the engine. [3/19]

An engine will operate most efficiently within a relatively narrow range of RPMs, and this is true whether it is a gasoline piston engine, a jet turbine, a steam engine, etc. But under different loads, like driving up a hill, you need a different amount of throttle. [2/19]

It looks like an interesting concept, albeit kind of tippy looking. I hope it turns out well. But promotions of miraculous new energy concepts have a long and storied history of not meeting the fanciful projections of the promoters. [fin/6]

One problem is that clustered turbines don’t work at peak efficiency. That’s why you see them spread out. If you cluster them together, their efficiency goes down. There is only so much energy to suck out of the wind. [5/6]
So for 100 turbines to each produce 100kW and power up to 100k homes, that would mean the homes have to use only 1000 watts. And that is at peak production efficiency of the turbine block. [4/6]
One 50-foot (17m) diameter conventional turbine can produce power at a peak rate of 100kW under ideal conditions. Note that kW is a rate of power production, not a quantity. [2/6]

And if the taxing authority wants to dispute an appraisal, then you enter into a lengthy process of argument and delay. Lawyers rack up fees. Bureaucracy expands. And remember how "mark to market" accelerated the problems of 2008-09?

@ThatIllusiveMan No, that case is not on point. (read it at https://t.co/5ddCjLfmxL). That case has to do with recognizing a new government in Cuba after Spain's withdrawal. It does not address the question of whether a treaty can take away powers specifically granted to the House.
Being a treaty, it would be “the supreme law of the land”. But that would bypass Article 1, Sec. 7 which grants the House that authority. So which authority would prevail? That’s a thorny one. [4/4]

So if the administration can somehow arrange a treaty that demands a certain tax rate, and can get that treaty ratified by the Senate (2/3rds vote required, which is tough), then it would theoretically be possible for a tax rate to be established with no House involvement. [3/4]

Article VI says that “This Constitution, and the Laws of the United States…, and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, under the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land.”  [2/4]

So if something has a high cost (again, don't confuse with "price"), you can know that it is tying up a bunch of inputs from energy, labor, and/or capital to produce. For example, electric vehicles.

My controversial assertion: The cost (not the price) of anything has only 3.5 inputs --
1: Energy
2: Labor
3: Capital
3.5: Land
What about the raw materials? OK, what does it take to source raw materials? Energy, labor, capital, & land. Land is .5 because cost is tied to capital.

In the story linked in that tweet, they talk about using wheat straw instead of logs for pulp to make paper. I'm all in favor of reducing waste. Typically wheat straw is plowed back under, returning nutrients to the field. If used for other purposes, more fertilizer is needed.

@ATLIHS Very true. A forest land owner who does not replant as soon as humanly possible after a harvest is a stupid one. Typically, forest owners are not stupid. They usually care more about their land than the lobbyists who seek to tell them what to do.
@SwanTommy Great example of how growth changes after a thinning.

Toilet (and other) paper is made from wood pulp, which usually comes from small diameter trees which are thinned to allow the remaining trees to fatten up and become 2x4s. Having a market for pulpwood increases the incentive to leave land in forest status. More TP = MORE forests.

@WEschenbach It is a fun mystery, and an even more fun correlation. Fun mysteries are useful, because they can help serve to point out how we collectively may not know as much as we think we know. I appreciate you contemplating it.

@WEschenbach Yes, that has indeed been known for a long time. That's why I used a 12-mo. rate-of-change (ROC) to smooth out the seasonality in the CO2 data. This allows us to see the trend underlying those seasonal changes, and its relationship to temps. Ocean temps remains best explanation.

So the choice is not about the CO2 released in burning wood vs. in burning natgas or coal, but rather in the net CO2 released by that displacement vs. letting the slash decompose on its own. That's the equation to take up and analyze. [3/3] @curryja @WAPolicyGreen

With no wood-burning for electrical generation, the slash has no value. So it gets left on the harvest site for termites, fungus, and bacteria to decompose. The termites fart methane (more potent GHG), and the other CO2 gets released anyway by decomp. [2/3]

The Arms Index is the ratio of the A/D Ratio and the Up/Down Volume Ratio. Most stocks are small caps, but most volume is traded by big caps. So a lopsided Arms Index tells a story about what the two different groups are doing.
Monday's raw Arms Index reading of 2.50 is the highest (i.e. most oversold) this year, sign of a short term price bottom.

Restating slightly, a sustained uptrend will see lots of days that produce new highs. And it is only the last new high that is the bearish one. So if you see a new high, odds are against it being that last one.

Good question. Comparing the VIX Index to whichever of its futures contracts is the lowest is a way to have a baseline for what the futures market thinks is the best possible case for future volatility. That way, we can better gauge the VIX's deviation from that baseline.

This is a really great illustration of an important point about breadth indicators generally. A modestly overbought condition can mark a top in a tepid market. But to get really overbought requires a lot of oomph, and thus it says there is more to come.

And both are aspects of the Law of Institutional Expertise: "The expert judgment of an institution, when the matters involve continuation of the institution's operations, is totally predictable, and hence the finding is totally worthless." (Dickson's "The Official Rules", 1978)

This is a modern variation on Kharasch's Institutional Imperative: "Every action or decision of an institution must be intended to keep the institution machinery working." (Washington lawyer Robert N. Kharasch, 1973).

@DanRusso_CMT Their key takeaways:
A halving event is when the reward for mining transactions is cut in half.
This event also cuts in half BTC's inflation rate and the rate at which new coins enter circulation.

So yes, it is a BTC event, but not one that changes speculation, just plumbing.

@factor_members I have looked once at Canadian (TSE) A-D data, and it was useless. Too many junior minors who rack up declines and then go broke or reorganize. I have not been able to find good sources for other world markets' A-D data.

@factor_members And don't go thinking that the Nasdaq is better. It's A-D Line has been falling since the beginning of the data, and has not ever made a new all-time high. It has a persistent bearish bias, so it is showing a divergence most of the time, which is not useful info. https://t.co/dF68q7WvE5

@factor_members The same analysts will tell you that you should watch the common only A-D numbers, since they are purer. But again, this is an untested hypothesis. I have found that the common only A-D Line is worse. Its divergences are often bad signals, except for one just recently. https://t.co/l6dIYfbeXd

@factor_members A lot of analysts think that the bond CEFs are a contaminant on the A-D data. But these analysts have not actually looked at the data, they just believe it and so that is why they believe it.

@factor_members In a similar vein, the A-D data for NYSE-listed bond CEFs give pretty good insights most of the time. No joy this year, but the Bond CEF A-D Line gave really nice divergences ahead of the Jan. 2018 and Sep. 2018 top. It has served well farther back too. https://t.co/C9PI3oxUmH

@factor_members If you want to look at issues that are REALLY sensitive to liquidity, watch the junk bonds. They trade like stocks more than like T-Bonds, and are supersensitive to liquidity, sometimes overly so. When they divergence, they are eventually right, but it can take a while. https://t.co/Y4ePZgOUp0

@factor_members The reason why the A-D Line is so useful is that it can detect liquidity problems before they show up in the big price indices. It is like the canaries in the coal mines of 200 years ago, which keeled over from bad gas before the big burly coal miners.

@factor_members Similarly, when the A-D Line is strong, that is usually an immunity card against the worst types of declines. Here is a chart to help illustrate that point. An A-D Line high usually means <10% drawdown. The exceptions came at the untapered ends of QE1&2, and with the Covid Crash. https://t.co/tvXhVokSvG

@factor_members I am pretty partial to the NYSE's A-D Line. It does not always give you a divergence every time you think you might like one. But when it does diverge, you better listen to it. https://t.co/upeTpDHL8p

@factor_members Oh, one final point. The 20th Amendment enacted in 1933 changed the political calendar in big ways. So periods before then should not be included in the PCP, as they were much different. 3rd years before then typically saw bear mkts (e.g. 1903, 1907, 1919).

@factor_members The 1 prior presidential term that the current one most resembles is Clinton 1 in 1993-97 (except for the weird inversion in Q4 2018). Notice that the period just ahead sees a bit of chop, but not nearly what the overall pattern suggests because of 1987's influence. [end thread] https://t.co/tE7jlvxFUw

@factor_members Here is that comparison again, zoomed in on recent data. Note the rocky time just ahead. But remember that the 1987 crash really bends the PCP at this point in time, making October worse than it typically is. https://t.co/gw35bp05Dl

@factor_members Here is the PCP versus the SPX during Trump's term. Notice that during 1st 2 years, correlation was horrible. Say it with me: "He's a different kind of president." But starting in Jan. 2019, suddenly correlation has become really tight. https://t.co/R0mrcAFq0D

@factor_members ... and running for reelection. The message is about how things are better now, and investors like that so they bid up prices. End of a 2nd term, anxiety rises because we are guaranteed to get a change, and people don't like that. So year 8 is a more iffy time, e.g. 2000, 2008.

@factor_members There is also a big difference in mkt behavior, esp. in 1st two years of a term, if you have a new guy or an incumbent. New guy typically spends 1st two years "discovering" things are even worse than he said, which bums out investors. Then spends final 2 declaring victory... https://t.co/1kqqr9qKZO

It is probably the same as the difficulty felt by people of my parents’ generation, trying to explain what it was like to have blackouts, block captains, gas-rationing, and victory gardens during World War II. [17/17]

I have tried to explain to my own children the fascination we all had for the space race back in the 1960s, but I sensed that my words come up short of conveying the full feelings of wonder and accomplishment that we all felt back then. [16/17]

It was many years later before I fully appreciated that Uncle Dick’s PhD in physics from Stanford University should have trumped the instruction book for my Instamatic camera when it came to the optics involved with taking photographs of a television. [15/?]
I had my doubts about what he was saying, and so just to be sure, I took one picture with a flash and one without. [14/?]

My Uncle Dick explained to me that I would not really need to use a flashbulb to take a picture of the television, since the screen itself was projecting light and thus did not need to be illuminated with a flash. [13/?]
There were four flash bulb chambers in each flash cube, and it automatically rotated with each shot of the camera. [12/?]

I knew that the Instamatic camera instructions stated that I should use a “flash cube” at night. A flash cube was a disposable square attachment which plugged into my camera and burned magnesium inside a plastic housing to create a flash to illuminate dark objects. [11/?]

Having just that year bought a Kodak 126 cartridge style “Instamatic” camera with my own money, I wanted to have a record of what we were seeing on TV. Remember that this was a day when home VCRs were still more than 10 years away from becoming a common appliance. [10/?]

There was a lot of cheering, and smiles on all of the faces, as everyone was proud and amazed at what we were witnessing. It was such a big deal that trading was suspended at the NYSE on Monday, July 21, 1969. [9/?]

We watched on my parents’ 19-inch black and white TV with rabbit ear antennae. Other guests also brought their TVs, and so there were probably 3 or 4 black and white TVs around the house, tuned into the different networks’ coverage. [8/?]

4 days later, Grampa Clem was back home to Los Angeles, and attending a party at my parents’ house. A large group of cousins and friends gathered at our house to watch the July 20th landing of the Lunar Module. [7/?]

My grandfather was invited to Cape Kennedy as a VIP to watch the July 16th launch of Apollo 11. He related that 100s of people who had been involved with that program were there with him in the temporary grandstands that NASA set up, all yelling things like, “Go, baby, go!” [6/?]
Because of my grandfather, I once got to meet Alan Shepard (the first American in space, and later commander of Apollo 14 who hit golf balls on the moon). [5/?]

He'd risen to be the director of the Griffith Park Observatory in Los Angeles, and was recruited by NASA to help train Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo astronauts in celestial navigation. It was necessary in order to make sure the Apollo ship was on the right course to the moon. [4/?]

Space and the moon-shot program were a big deal in our family. My maternal grandfather, Clarence Cleminshaw, had given up his Harvard law school education and a promising career as a lawyer in the late 1920s to pursue a PhD in astronomy. [3/?]

The Apollo program was the pinnacle of the space race, and on July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed on the moon and took a walk around. They did all of this on live TV, which was incredible. [2/?]
50 years ago this week, I wanted to be an astronaut. That is not very remarkable, since just about every 8 year old boy back then wanted to be an astronaut. [1/?]

More historical tidbits. The NYSE traded on Saturdays back then. The DJIA was actually up slightly on Saturday, May 11, 1940, despite the invasion news from May 10. By Mon. May 13, though, traders had more time to digest the news. DJI lost 21.2% between May 10 and 21, 1940.

May 13, 1940 was the Monday after Hitler invaded France, Netherlands, and Belgium on Friday May 10. FDR froze those countries' assets in the U.S., Churchill took over as PM after Chamberlain had resigned May 10. DJIA fell 4.98% on May 13. So yeah, lots going on that day.

@cschwimer21 The Oscillator is the difference between a 10% Trend (19EMA) and 5% Trend (39EMA) of the daily A-D. When both EMAs get up to a high level, and then a bit of neg. breadth appears, it is easier to pull the 10%T down far below the 5%T, hence the big negative reading.

@swingtrader20 Nope, not a quantity, but a rate of production or usage of electricity. A watt-hour, or a MW-hour, is a quantity. So a 100-watt bulb consumes juice at a rate of 100 watts. If you burn it for 10 hours, you'll consume 1 kw-hour, which is the quantity of juice you'll be charged for.

@swingtrader20 First, a MW is not a quantity, it is a rate, like 55 MPH. Second, a 2MW turbine refers to the maximum possible output under ideal wind conditions, not what it produces all the time. Third, you're changing the subject.

Turbines are neither green nor carbon neutral. They kill birds and bats. Each 2MW turbine has a concrete base which requires 750 cu. yds. or concrete, which emits 262,500 pounds of CO2 before the blades ever spin. The blades are made from petroleum products & have 12-15 yr. life.

"The Great Depression" got its name partly due to its severity, but also from the fashion of calling everything "great" then, e.g. The Great War, Gatsby, White Hope. Economists began substituting "recession" because they did not want to invoke the idea of another event that bad.

Now that we have made some progress in getting people to abandon the whole silly notion of “10% = correction, 20% = bear market”, there is another bit of terminology to work on. Some people think a “recession” is just a gentler type of depression. They are wrong. https://t.co/7L0liuABqJ

To get a (Martin) Zweig Breadth Thrust (ZBT) signal, we'd need 10-day EMA of A/(A+D) to go from below 0.40 to above 0.615 within 10 trading days. So it has until Jan. 10. Today gets that # up to 0.587 (prelim). Chart is not up to date, shows last few ZBTs. 2015 was a big fail. https://t.co/R7nDWyWQag
